speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Good afternoon.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Federal Open Market Committee concluded a two-day meeting earlier today.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As always, my colleagues and I reviewed recent economic and financial developments and discussed the economic outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The data since our January meeting have been generally consistent with our expectation that the fourth-quarter pause in the recovery would prove temporary and that moderate economic growth would resume.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Spending by households and businesses has continued to expand, and the housing sector has seen further gains.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The jobs market has also shown signs of improvement over the past six months or so: Private payrolls are growing more quickly, total hours of work have increased, the rate of filings of new claims for unemployment insurance has fallen, and the unemployment rate has continued to tick down.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, at 7.7 percent, the unemployment rate remains elevated.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee also remains concerned that restrictive fiscal policies may slow economic growth and job creation in coming months.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We continue to monitor the recent increases in gasoline prices, which appear to be due mostly to passing factors such as refinery shutdowns for maintenance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Apart from temporary variations in energy prices, inflation is running somewhat below the Committee’s longer-run objective of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Importantly, longer-term inflation expectations remain stable.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Overall, still-high unemployment, in combination with relatively low inflation, underscores the need for policies that will support progress towards maximum employment in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In conjunction with this meeting, the 19 participants in our policy discussion—the 7 Board members and 12 Reserve Bank presidents—submitted individual economic projections.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: March 20, 2013 As always, each participant’s projections are conditioned on his or her own view of appropriate Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: To summarize, the participants’ projections for economic growth have a central tendency of 2.3 to 2.8 percent for 2013, rising to 2.9 to 3.7 percent in 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The central tendency of their projections of the unemployment rate for the fourth quarter of this year is 7.3 to 7.5 percent, declining to 6.0 to 6.5 percent in the final quarter of 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Most participants see inflation gradually increasing toward the Committee’s longer-run target; the central tendency of their projections for inflation is 1.3 to 1.7 percent this year and 1.7 to 2.0 percent in 2015.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As you already know from the policy statement, we are continuing the asset purchase program first announced in September.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: This decision was supported by our review at the meeting of the likely efficacy, costs, and risks of additional purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me briefly summarize the cost–benefit analysis supporting our decision.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Although estimates of the efficacy of the Federal Reserve’s asset purchases are necessarily uncertain, most participants agreed that these purchases—by putting downward pressure on longer-term interest rates, including mortgage rates—continue to provide meaningful support to economic growth and job creation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: However, most also agreed that this monetary tool would likely not be able on its own to fully offset major economic headwinds, such as those that might arise from significant near-term fiscal restraint or from a sharp increase in global financial stresses.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We also had a thorough discussion of possible costs and risks of continued expansion of the Federal Reserve’s balance sheet.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The risks include possible adverse implications of additional purchases for the functioning of securities markets, and the potential effects—under various scenarios—of a larger balance sheet on the Federal Reserve’s earnings from its asset holdings and, hence, on its remittances to the Treasury.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The Committee also considered possible March 20, 2013 risks to financial stability, such as might arise if persistently low rates lead some market Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL participants to take on excessive risk in a “reach for yield.” In the Committee’s view, these costs remain manageable but will continue to be monitored, and we will take them into appropriate account as we determine the size, pace, and composition of our asset purchases.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As for today, our policy decision had two main elements.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: First, the Committee decided to continue purchasing additional agency mortgage-backed securities at a pace of $40 billion per month and longer-term Treasury securities at a pace of $45 billion per month.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It bears emphasizing that the Committee has described this program in terms of a monthly pace of purchases, rather than as a total amount of expected purchases, and has tied the evolution of the program to economic criteria—specifically, to the achievement of a substantial improvement in the outlook for the labor market in a context of price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Within this framework, the Committee could vary the pace of purchases as progress is made toward its economic objectives or if its assessment of the efficacy and costs of the program changes.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: At this meeting, the Committee judged that no adjustment was warranted.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Second, the Committee kept the target for the federal funds rate at 0 to ¼ percent and reaffirmed its expectation that a highly accommodative stance of monetary policy will remain appropriate for a considerable time after the asset purchase program ends and the economic recovery strengthens.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, we anticipate that this exceptionally low range for the funds rate will be appropriate at least as long as the unemployment rate remains above 6½ percent, inflation between one and two years ahead is projected to be no more than a half percentage point above the Committee’s longer-run inflation goal of 2 percent, and longer-term inflation expectations continue to be well anchored.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I should note, as I have on other occasions, that the economic conditions provided in this forward guidance are thresholds, not triggers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Crossing one or more of these thresholds will not lead automatically to an increase in rates.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Rather, the Committee will assess at that time whether the outlook justifies raising its target for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: This guidance will help market participants assess how the Federal Reserve’s interest rate policy is likely to respond to economic developments, but its broader purpose is to assure households and businesses that monetary policy will continue to support the recovery even as the pace of economic growth and job creation picks up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In their individual projections, 14 of the 19 FOMC participants saw the first increase in the target for the federal funds rate as occurring in 2015 or 2016.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Let me comment briefly on how the two main pieces of our policy accommodation—asset purchases and guidance about future changes in the federal funds rate—fit together.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The purpose of the asset purchases is to increase the economy’s near-term momentum, with the goal of improving the outlook for the labor market and helping to promote a self-sustaining recovery with price stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The forward rate guidance, in turn, provides information about when the Committee will begin considering the removal of policy accommodation through increases in the target for the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Importantly, the Committee expects a considerable interval to pass between the time when the Committee will cease adding accommodation through asset purchases and the time when it will be appropriate to begin removing accommodation by moving the federal funds rate target toward more normal levels.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: As always, in deciding on the appropriate stance of policy, the Committee will take a balanced approach consistent with its longer-run goals of maximum employment and inflation of 2 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In sum, the Committee anticipates moderate economic growth, supported by household and business spending and a strengthening housing sector.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The labor market has shown signs of March 20, 2013 improvement in recent months, but the unemployment rate remains elevated.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Inflation is Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL expected to remain low, and fiscal policy has become somewhat more restrictive.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In light of its outlook, and following a review of the efficacy and costs of additional asset purchases, the Committee today reaffirmed its asset purchase program and its federal funds guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Thank you very much.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would be glad to take your questions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, to take your second question first, the lack of thresholds comes from the complexity of the problem.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the one hand, we have benefits, which are associated with improvements in the economy, but there are also costs associated with unconventional policy, such as potential effects on financial stability, which are hard to quantify and which people have different views about.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, to this point, we’ve not been able to give quantitative thresholds for the asset purchases in the same way that we have for the federal funds rate target.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re going to continue to try to provide information as we go forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, as I mentioned today, as we make progress towards our objective, we may adjust the flow rate of purchases month to month to appropriately calibrate the amount of accommodation we’re providing given the outlook for the labor market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of further color, again, given the complexity of the issue, we’ve not given quantitative analysis or quantitative thresholds.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would say that we’ll be looking for sustained March 20, 2013 improvement in a range of key labor market indicators, including, obviously, payrolls, Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL unemployment rate, but also others like the hiring rate, claims for unemployment insurance, quit rates, wage rates, and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ll be looking for sustained improvement across a range of indicators, and in a way that’s taking place throughout the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And since we’re looking at the outlook—we’re looking at the prospects rather than the current state of the labor market— we’ll also be looking at things like growth to try to understand whether there’s sufficient momentum in the economy to provide demand for labor going forward.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that will allow us to look through, perhaps, some temporary fluctuations associated with short-term shocks or problems.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, the problem with having just a single criterion is that it’s all or nothing.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We maintain full speed ahead until we hit a certain target, and then, you know, we stop.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That would be, I think, very difficult for the markets to understand, to anticipate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We think it makes more sense to have our policy variable, which is the rate of flow of purchases, respond in a more continuous or sensitive way to changes in the outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, as we make progress towards our ultimate objective of substantial improvement, we may adjust the rate of flow of purchases accordingly.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, we won’t do that every meeting; we won’t do that frequently.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But when we see that the condition or the situation has changed in a meaningful way, then we may well adjust the pace of purchases in order to keep the level of accommodation March 20, 2013 consistent with the outlook, and, secondly, to help provide the markets with some sense of Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL progress—how much progress is being made so that it can make better judgments.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, you know, as I just described what I mean by “substantial improvement,” it’s a broad-based improvement in a range of indicators as well as improvement in output and labor demand.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, as we move—we see partial improvements, see modest improvement, as we see a period in which the labor market is doing better, and we have reason to think it might be stronger, then we might reduce accommodation at that point.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But it works in both directions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If, subsequently, the labor market were to weaken, the outlook were to get worse, we could, of course, bring back accommodation back to the previous level.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, that’s going to be obviously a decision that the Committee has to make, and we will—at each meeting, we’ll look at progress that’s been made since the last meeting, try to assess the outlook, try to determine whether there’s been a sufficient change to warrant a change in our policy stance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Internally, we’ll use models and other indicators of the state of the labor market to try to make a good estimate of how much we need to change the rate of flow.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, again, the point of this is to let the market see our behavior, to let them see how we respond to changes in the outlook.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And that way there will be a better ability, I March 20, 2013 hope, for the markets to anticipate either a return to higher levels of purchases or the ultimate Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL phasing-out of the program.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That’s an issue for—obviously, there has been improvement, let me say that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’ve seen improvement in the last four or five months.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The last five months, for example, we’ve seen over 200,000 jobs a month in the private sector.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Unemployment rate has come down four-tenths since September.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Unemployment claims, insurance claims are at the lowest level they’ve been since the crisis, so we are seeing improvement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think one thing we would need is to make sure that this is not a temporary improvement.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we’ve seen periods before where we had as many as 300,000 jobs for a couple of months, and then things weakened again.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, first, on the reverberations, it’s a difficult situation in Cyprus.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You’ve got a situation where the banking system is a large multiple of the size of the March 20, 2013 economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And so, in the financial sense, it’s bigger than it is in a GDP sense.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And it’s a Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL difficult problem because the country faces both fiscal and bank capitalization issues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And you’ve seen that there’s political stress in terms of trying to figure out how they’re going to meet the demands of the euro group for contributing to their rescue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, there are a lot of uncertainties and difficulties, and there’s questions about how—the way Cyprus is treated, what implications that might have for other countries and the like.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, it does have some consequence.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, having said that, you know, the vote failed and the markets are up today, and I don’t think that the impact has been enormous.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, I think it’s something we’re paying attention to.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We hope that the Europeans will come up with an efficient and equitable solution.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are monitoring very carefully, but, at this point, we’re not seeing a major risk to the U.S. financial system or the U.S. economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the benefits of being too big to fail, no, we don’t have an estimate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It’s pretty difficult to control for all the factors that go into determining the size of the subsidy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think there is some evidence that financial markets are, at least to some extent, taking into account the possibility that large financial institutions will fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You see, for example, spreads in the credit default swaps that indicate some probability of failure.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You see some discrimination among different institutions according to the bond market—interest rates that they get charged, and so on.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So there is some evidence of market discrimination.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, I certainly never meant to say to Senator Warren—and I share her concern about too-big-to-fail, I think it’s a major issue—I never meant to imply that the problem was solved and gone.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It is not solved and gone; it’s still here, but there’s a lot of work in train.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re putting in the Basel capital standards.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re putting in the orderly liquidation authority from Dodd–Frank.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re working with our international partners.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I hope that we’ll make March 20, 2013 progress against too-big-to-fail, because I agree with her 100 percent that it’s a real problem and Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL needs to be addressed if at all possible.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, on the latter question, I don’t have anything for you.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’ll certainly be informing the Wall Street Journal and other publications if I come to some decision or some developments in that front.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of term limits, I don’t have a strong view on that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Different countries use different approaches.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Of course, the President always has the option to reappoint or not reappoint Fed Chairmen, and the Senate always has the option of confirming or not confirming.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, in that respect, term limits are redundant.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, indeed, if you had term limits on the Fed Chairman, that would be, I think, the only office in the federal government besides President and Vice President that would have that restriction.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But that being said, again, I don’t view this as a major issue, nor have I seen it actively discussed in, I think, in the Hill.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Perhaps I missed it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I don’t have a strong view about that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: My 10-year term, of course, is not as Chairman.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: My 10-year remaining term is as a Governor, so that’s not relevant, really, to the question that you asked about.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Pretty recently.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I have a relative that is unemployed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I come from a small town in South Carolina that has taken a big hit from the recession.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Last time I was there, the unemployment rate was about 15 percent.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think it’s better now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: The home that I was raised in had just been foreclosed upon when I was visiting there.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I have great concern about the unemployed both for their own sake, but also because the loss of skills, the loss of labor force attachment is bad for our whole economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It reduces tax revenues.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It reduces productivity.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think it’s very, very important that we act to address unemployment, and I think the Federal Reserve—I think most people would agree—the Federal Reserve has been fairly active in that regard.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of costs, there are a number of different costs, and I mentioned some of them in my remarks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think one that has recently been discussed—Governor Stein brought it up in a speech—is the issue of financial stability.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Clearly, financial instability, if it were allowed to be sufficiently serious, would be a threat to employment, a threat to jobs, and a threat to production.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, obviously, given the experience of the past few years, we want to be sure that we’re not unnecessarily encouraging excessive risk-taking or other problems in the financial markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do address that through a number of means, including monitoring the financial system, regulation, supervision, communication, and the like.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But this is a potential concern that a March 20, 2013 number of my colleagues are worried about, and it’s one of the things we talked about in our Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL discussion of the costs and risks of balance sheet policies.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I don’t know what you mean by “on the table.” BINYAMIN APPELBAUM.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, again, I don’t—we’ve not been able to come to an agreement about what guidance we should give.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And part of the concern is—is that as we go forward, we—you know, we’ll have to factor in the efficacy, which is another issue.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, there’s a wide range of views about how effective asset purchases are in terms of moving the economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, as we move forward in time, we’ll be learning about how effective the policy is, and what costs and risks there may be associated with it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, as we do that, perhaps we will be able to give more-explicit guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I agree with you 100 percent that that would be more effective if we could give numerical guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, you know, I think the Federal Reserve has come a long way.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: You know, in 1994, we didn’t even tell people when we changed the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Now, we’re telling you when—you know, what the state of the economy is going to be when we raise the federal funds rate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, we are making progress in terms of forward guidance.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I think capital is an important element in addressing too-big-to-fail.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One of the things that will be proposed, and is not in effect yet, will be surcharges on the largest banks—that is, the largest financial institutions will have to hold more capital as a percent of their risk-weighted assets than smaller banks do.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That will increase their cost of funding and, to some extent, will both equalize their cost of funding with other banks and make them safer so that the risk of their failure is limited.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So I think that’s an important step.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And there are many other restrictions in both Dodd–Frank and Basel, including liquidity restrictions and so on, that apply most strictly to the largest institutions.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In terms of the financing, it is true, I think, that excessive reliance on short-term uninsured funding does present some risks.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And there are different ways to address that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But one way to address it is through liquidity regulation.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And both in our 165–166 rule and now through Basel III, we will be putting forward restrictions on the kinds of financing, the limits on how much illiquidity and liquidity risk firms can take.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Again, I don’t think too-big-to-fail is solved now.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re doing a number of things, which I think will help.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We need to keep assessing that, and we’ll be able to tell by looking at market indicators, by doing our own stress tests and the like.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And if we don’t, you know, if we don’t achieve the goal, I think we’ll have to do additional steps.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It is important.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, it’s not something we can just forget about.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It may take some time, but too-big-to-fail was a major part of the source of the crisis.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And we will not have successfully responded to the crisis if we don’t address that problem successfully.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, the tightening of credit in mortgage markets—I mean, our sense is that it’s gone too far.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I mean, some tightening was obviously needed.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: There were people who bought houses prior to the crisis who really couldn’t sustain a mortgage.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, terms and conditions have been tightened up, and we’re now seeing much higher credit quality requirements on potential borrowers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We are concerned that a variety of factors, such as concerns about putbacks the banks may have, uncertainties about regulation—which we’re working on to get done as quickly as possible—may have tightened the mortgage credit box more than would be desirable in a long-run healthy economy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That does have some effect on monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: One of the most powerful tools we have is bringing down mortgage rates and stimulating homebuying, construction, and related industries.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So that is an issue that we take into account.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I would say one thing, which is that as the housing industry has strengthened and home prices have gone up, that has actually brought some people into the credit box in the sense that the number of people, for example, who are underwater on their mortgages is declining as house prices go up.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, as people have bigger down payments, bigger equity in their homes, they become more creditworthy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, to some extent, not—I don’t want to overstate it—but to some extent, monetary policy—by strengthening the housing market, helping support house prices—is bringing more people into the mortgage market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That’s right.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re not targeting asset prices.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re not measuring success in terms of the stock market.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re measuring success in terms of our mandate, which is employment and price stability, and that’s what we’re trying to achieve.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We do monitor the entire financial system, not just the parts that we supervise or regulate.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It includes the stock market and other asset markets.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We use a variety of metrics.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I don’t want to, now, be pulled into going through every individual financial market and assessing it.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But, in the stock market, you know, we don’t see at this point anything that’s out of line with historical patterns.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In particular, you should remember, of course, that while the Dow may be hitting a high, it’s in nominal terms, it’s not in real terms.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, our analysis is fairly comparable to analysis that the Congressional Budget Office has presented to the Congress.

sentence: And they estimate that putting together all the fiscal measures, including the fiscal cliff deal, the sequester, and other cuts, that federal fiscal restraint in 2013 is cutting something like 1½ percentage points off of growth, which, of course, is very significant.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE

sentence: Well, the reason for publishing the severely adverse scenario, of course, is that’s the ultimate acid test, you know, whether the banks are sufficiently March 20, 2013 capitalized.

sentence: We have—as you know, we have given this guideline for—so we call them signposts for how the funds rate is going to evolve over time.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And, as a lot of academic research shows, you know, when you’re close to the zero lower bound, by telling markets that you’re going to keep rates low for a significant period, that’s one way to get longer-term rates down and to provide more stimulus to the economy.

sentence: And they may have led—and I say “may” because the statistical experts—many of them deny it, but it’s possible that they led job creation and GDP to be exaggerated to some extent early in the year.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE

sentence: For example, the number of people who are out of the labor force but say they would like a full-time job but are not actually counted as unemployed, that number has actually been going up, which suggests that there are more people thinking about going back into the labor force, going back to work.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I doubt that, in the near term at least, that we’ll see an increase in labor force participation because—besides the effects of the slow recovery, high unemployment, we’ve had a downward trend in the U.S., which is not due to the recession, it’s due to underlying demographic factors.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Well, I still believe the following, which is that monetary policy is a very blunt instrument.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: If you are raising interest rates to pop an asset bubble, even if you were sure you can do that, you might, at the same time, be throwing the economy into recession, which kind of defeats the purpose of monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And therefore, I think the first March 20, 2013 line of defense—I mean, I think, we have a sort of a tripartite line of defense.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We start off with Chairman Bernanke’s Press Conference FINAL very extensive and sophisticated monitoring at a much higher level and much more comprehensively than we’ve had in the past.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: Then we have supervision and regulation, where we work with other agencies to try to cover all the empty or uncovered areas in the financial system.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And then, in addition, we try to use communication and similar tools to affect the way that financial markets respond to monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So we do have some first lines of defense, which I think should be used first.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: That being said, you know, I think that given the problems that we’ve had—not just in the United States, but globally in the last 15, 20 years—that we need to at least take into account these issues as we make monetary policy.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: And I think most of the people on the FOMC would agree with that.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I think if the economy is in very weak condition and interest rates are very low for that purpose, it’s very difficult to contemplate raising rates a lot because you’re concerned about some sector in the financial sphere.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: On the other hand, if you’re in an expansion and there’s a credit boom going on, that—the case in that situation for making policy a little bit tighter might be better.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: So, as I’ve said many times, I have an open mind in this question.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: We’re learning; all central bankers are learning.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: But I think I still would agree with the point I made in my very first speech in 2002, as a Governor at the Federal Reserve, where I argued that the first line of defense ought to be the more targeted tools that we have, including regulatory tools and, to some extent, macroprudential tools like some emerging markets use.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: I’ve spoken to the President a bit, but I really don’t have any—I don’t really have any information for you at this juncture.

sentence: I don’t think that I’m the only person in the world who can manage the exit.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: In fact, one of the things that I hope to accomplish, and was not entirely successful at, as the Governor or as the Chairman of the Federal Reserve, was to try to depersonalize, to some extent, monetary policy and financial policy and to get broader recognition of the fact that this is an extraordinary institution.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It has a large number of very high quality policymakers.

speaker: CHAIRMAN BERNANKE
sentence: It has a terrific staff—literally dozens of Ph.D. economists who’ve been working through the crisis, trying to understand these issues and implement our policy tools, and there’s no single person who is essential to that.

sentence: But, again, with respect to my personal plans, I will certainly let you know when I have something more concrete.
